hints.content: Start by understanding the problem. You need to cover all travel days with the minimum cost using three types of tickets: 1-day, 7-day, and 30-day passes.
Consider using dynamic programming to solve this problem. You can maintain an array where each index represents the minimum cost to cover travel up to that day.
Initialize a cost array, `dp`, where `dp[i]` will store the minimum cost to travel up to day `i`. The size of this array should be at least 366 to accommodate all days of the year.
You can iterate through each travel day in the `days` array and calculate the cost for each type of ticket. Make sure to only update costs for the days you are traveling.
For each travel day, consider three scenarios: buying a 1-day pass, buying a 7-day pass, and buying a 30-day pass. Use the costs array to determine the cost for each option.
When calculating the cost for a 7-day pass, make sure to account for the last 7 days covered by the pass. You should compare the current cost with the cost from 7 days prior.
Similarly, for the 30-day pass, ensure you are considering the cost from 30 days prior. This means you need to check the minimum cost accumulated up to that point.
Don't forget to handle days that are not in the `days` array. You can simply carry forward the previous minimum cost for those days.
Make sure to initialize your `dp` array properly. Start with `dp[0] = 0` (cost of traveling before day 1) and fill it based on the travel days provided.
At the end of your iterations, the answer will be found in `dp[365]`, which represents the minimum cost to cover all travel days in the year.

questionNotes: The `days` array is strictly increasing and contains unique travel days.
The costs array has exactly three elements corresponding to the costs of the 1-day, 7-day, and 30-day passes.
Ensure that your solution handles edge cases, such as when all travel days fall within a single pass duration.
